text.content:
Welcome to the Third Horizon, traveler of the stars. Along your journey, you will experience marvelous things. Ahead lies intrigue and the Dark between the Stars. The struggle for the Horizon has started – only the Icons themselves know how it will end.

This expansion modernizes the Coriolis: The Hird Horizon combat rules, drawing inspiration from other Year Zero Engine RPGs (such as ALIEN and Coriolis: The Great Dark), as well as community house rules. It remains fully compatible with the Core Rulebook and existing Talents. It expands on the 3-action system with inspirations from Shadowrun and Pathfinder 2E, changes Darkness with random events, adjusts character advancement options, and expands the stress mechanic with panic and mental trauma.

Attributions:

  • Thank you Fria Ligan for bringing us the Coriolis RPG’s and the Year Zero Engine.
  • Thank you Fria Ligan for bringing us the Coriolis RPG’s and the Year Zero Engine.Cover art is by ptitvinc from deviantart [Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-No Derivatives Works 3.0 License]

Combat begins when you attack an enemy, or when an enemy attacks you. The story is then zoomed in to an action scene.

 

Rounds & Initiative

Action scenes are played out in rounds, each approximately 6 seconds long. Initiative determines the order in which combatants act each round.

 

Taking The Initiative

To determine the initiative, roll 1D6 plus your Agility or Wits, whichever is lowest. The result of all initiative rolls determines the order in which they act in the round from highest to lowest. This is a passive roll. 

Ready Weapon: If you are not surprised and carry a weapon at the ready (not stowed away), you may draw it automatically before rolling initiative. That weapon provides a bonus to your initiative.

Ties: On a tie with an NPC, the NPC acts first. On a tie with another PC, decide between each other who goes first.

Your Turn: Your turn is your place in the initiative order. When all participants have acted, the round ends and a new round begins with fresh actions. (see Actions on page 8)

Additional Turns: Some exceptional beings have abilities that allow them to take more than one turn per round, rolling additional initiative rolls.

 

Surprise Attacks

When you want to stalk someone or ambush them and your attack catches them unaware, it’s called a surprise attack. 

First, roll your INFILTRATION versus your target’s OBSERVATION. You get a modification depending on how close you want to go, and a further bonus if you lie in wait for an ambush when they come close. See the table below. 

For a melee ambush, you must reach ENGAGED range (usually within Close range, 2 meters). If you fail your INFILTRATION, your target spots you before you close the distance and initiative is rolled normally.

If you succeed, you get a +3 bonus on the initiative roll, an extra action on the first round and your target cannot use Reactive Actions until they have had their first turn. 

Surprise Attack - Infiltration

Range

Modification

Engaged / Close

-2

Near

-1

Short

0

Long

+1

Extreme

+3

*Lie in ambush

+2 (additional)

 

 

Holding Off

On your turn, you may ‘hold off’, delaying your action until after another combatant this round. Your new initiative position is permanently lowered for the rest of combat

Help from Others: In most cases, you will need to be at the same initiative as the person you’re helping.

Note: All rules effects that are triggered “on your turn”, are moved in the turn order until your new initiative turn starts. Your turn doesn’t happen until you use it.

Range

In combat, the distance between you and your enemy is divided into five categories. If you use a map with a square of hexagonal grid, usually they use 1 grid space for every 2 meters.

u  Close: up to about 2 meters (1 space)

u  Near: up to about 4 meters (2 spaces)

u  Short: up to about 20 meters (10 spaces)

u  Long: up to about 100 meters (50 spaces)

u  Extreme: up to about one kilometer

Actions

Each round you have 3 Action Points. Actions are also referred to as activities – these cost 1 ⦿, 2 ⦿⦿, or three ⦿⦿⦿ Action Points. Activities cannot be split over multiple rounds.

Action Reset: All actions are refreshed at the start of a new combat round. Action Points can never be saved from one round to the next.

Free Actions (◯): These can be done at any time and do not cost an Action Point. Most are passive dice rolls.

Reactive Actions (⟣): These can be used outside your own turn. You can only use these if you have Action Points left, unless you Exert Yourself. 

Each time you use a Reactive Action, you lose Action Points in the round, and if you have already used your actions, you can’t use them. When it’s your time to act, it might therefore be wise to save some actions if you fear you might be attacked later in the round.

NPCs don’t take Reactive Actions in general. A GM can consume 1 Darkness to have a (major) NPC take a Reactive Action. This still costs actions as normal.

Exert Yourself: Take 1 stress to gain 1 Action Point, which is only usable for a Reactive Action. You can do this multiple times. You do not make a Panic Roll when taking this stress.

 

Action Table

Movement Activities

⦿ MOVE

You can move up to your Movement rate (default 6 meters). Moving past obstacles may require a DEXTERITY test at the GM’s discretion.

Crawling, sneaking, moving in darkness, or crossing difficult terrain halves your Movement rate. When you crawl, you are PRONE.

When you move within close combat range of an enemy (usually 2 meters), you are ENGAGED. If you move away from an ENGAGED enemy, they get a free Melee Attack or Quick Shot against you. The free attack doesn’t count toward their actions in the round and you can’t block it using reactive actions.

 

⦿ GET UP

You stand up and are no longer PRONE.

 

⦿ Leap

You can run up to half your Movement rate and make a horizontal leap as part of it. Leaps of 3 meters or more require a successful DEXTERITY test to make it. Apply a -1 modifier for each meter beyond 3 meters.

See page 22 for rules about damage resulting from falling.

 

⦿ RETREAT

You try to carefully retreat from an enemy and move half your Movement rate. If you are ENGAGED with an active enemy, roll a DEXTERITY test. If you fail, you still move but your enemy gets a free Melee Attack or Quick Shot against you. The free attack doesn’t count toward their actions in the round and you can’t block it using reactive actions.

 

⦿ OPEN DOOR OR HATCH

You try to open a door or hatch. Unlocked doors open automatically. Locked doors require a Break Something or Interact with Technology activity. (see page 15)

 

⦿ TAKE COVER

If you stand in or besides cover, you actively position and crouch yourself to take benefit from it from ranged attacks.

Your Armor Rating is increased against ranged attacks depending on the type of cover.

COVER TYPES

Cover

Armor Rating

Divan or Shrubbery

4

Furniture

6

Door

8

Inner bulkhead or wall

10

Outer bulkhead or wall

12

Armored bulkhead or wall

  14+

Foxhole

16

*Armor Rating from Cover is halved against explosions and grenades

 

 

Close Combat Activities

⦿⦿ MELEE ATTACK

To attack an opponent in close combat, you need to be standing on your feet and be ENGAGED. (usually within 2 meters)

If you are PRONE, you must Get Up before you can attack. While prone, standing enemies get a +2 modification on all close combat attacks against you.

Roll a MELEE COMBAT test, modified by the bonus of your weapon. If your test is successful, your attack hits and you inflict damage equal to the weapon’s Damage rating on your opponent. 

Damage may be mitigated by armor. Read more about damage, armor, and critical hits on page 16.

STUNTS: For every extra 6 you roll, choose one of these stunts:

u  Increase Damage: You inflict one additional point of damage. You can choose this stunt multiple times, if you roll several 6’s.

u  Critical Injury: You inflict a critical injury on your enemy. This effect costs extra sixes (beyond the first one) equal to your weapon’s Crit Rating.
By spending even more sixes, for each extra 6 you can roll an extra time on the D66 critical injury table and choose one result.

u  Outflank: You out-maneuver your enemy. You swap your initiative score with them, taking effect next Round. You can’t go back to your earlier initiative.

u  Strike Fear: You strike fear into your enemy. They suffer 1 stress. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

u  Disarm: Your target drops a weapon or another hand-held object to the floor. You choose which.

u  Trip: Your opponent falls PRONE. This stunt can only be used on humanoid opponents.

u  Grapple: You pin your enemy in a tight clinch. This stunt can normally only be used on humanoid opponents. If your opponent uses Block Melee, you both automatically fall to the ground and are PRONE. The opponent drops any weapon they were holding and cannot move. The only action they can perform is Break Free. While you are grappling, the only action you can perform (apart from releasing your opponent) is a Quick Jab.

 

⦿ QUICK JAB

You take a quick jab at an opponent. Quick jabs can only be made unarmed or with a Light weapon. 

This counts as a Melee Attack with a -2 modifier to the MELEE COMBAT test. You cannot use the Disarm, Trip or Grapple stunts on a Quick Jab.

 

⦿ SHOVE

You can try to shove an opponent at ENGAGED range away from you. This is done with a MELEE COMBAT test. The GM can add modifications to your roll for certain opponents. 

On a success, your opponent is shoved 2 meters away. Shoves count as a close combat attack and as such can be blocked.

 

⟣ BLOCK MELEE

If you are attacked in close combat, you can choose to block the attack, to avoid being hit. You must declare that you are going to block before the attacker rolls for their strike. Roll a MELEE COMBAT test. NPCs consume 1 Darkness when they use this action.

If you are unarmed, you have a -2 modifier for the test.

For each 6 you roll, choose an effect below:

u  Defend: You remove one of the enemy’s 6. If they are left with no 6, the attack misses. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

u  Counterattack: You perform a counterattack, dealing damage to the attacker equal to the Damage rating of your weapon. You cannot spend additional 6’s to use the Increase Damage stunt.

u  Disarm: You disarm your enemy after they have made their attack.

 

⦿⦿ BREAK FREE

You attempt to break free from a grapple. Make an opposed MELEE COMBAT test. On a success, you are no longer grappled and roll 1 meter away. Usually this means you’re still ENGAGED.

 

Ranged Combat Activities

⦿ AIM

If you take your time to aim at your target carefully before squeezing the trigger, you get a +2 modifier to your next RANGED COMBAT roll. You cannot aim multiple times.

The aim bonus is lost when:

u  You take a different action than Shoot at your target

u  You take health damage

u  Your target takes a Move, Leap or Retreat action

 

⦿⦿ SHOOT

When you shoot at someone from a distance, roll

for RANGED COMBAT, modified by the bonus of your weapon and other applicable modifiers. 

RANGED COMBAT MODIFICATIONS

Factor

Modification

Aimed Shot

+2

Engaged

-3

Close range (not Engaged)

+3

Near / Short range

-

Long range

-1

Extreme range

-2

Beyond Weapon Range

-3

Very Large target

+2

Very Small target

-2

Target is PRONE

-1

Dim light

-1

Darkness

-2

You need to be able to see your target. You also need a ranged weapon, even if it’s simply something to throw. If your test is successful, your attack hits and you inflict damage equal to the weapon’s Damage rating on your opponent. 

If your test is unsuccessful you miss. If your target was ENGAGED with another player, the GM can spend 1 Darkness. This will result in friendly fire – you inflict damage equal to the weapon’s Damage rating on the other combatant and gain 1 stress.

Damage may be mitigated by armor and cover. See the Take Cover action and the Armor & Cover section.

STUNTS: For every extra 6 you roll, choose one of these stunts:

u  Increase Damage: You inflict one additional point of damage. You can choose this stunt multiple times, if you roll several 6’s.

u  Critical Injury: You inflict a critical injury on your enemy. This effect costs extra sixes (beyond the first one) equal to your weapon’s Crit Rating.

By spending even more sixes, for each extra 6 you can roll an extra time on the D66 critical injury table and choose one result.

u  Outflank: You out-maneuver your enemy and get to exchange your initiative score with them, taking effect next Round. You can’t go back to your earlier initiative.

u  Aggressive Fire: You strike fear into your enemy. They take 1 point of stress. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

u  Disarm: Your target drops a weapon or another hand-held object to the floor. You choose which.

u  Startle: Your target falls PRONE or is pushed back 2 meter. You cannot use this stunt if they are Grappling.

 

⦿⦿⦿ FULL AUTO FIRE

You can only take this action if you shoot using a firearm with the Automatic fire feature.

You fire a long burst of full auto fire. This counts as a normal Shoot action, but with a few differences:

u  You get a +2 modification to your roll.

u  You take 1 point of stress.

u  You can distribute any additional 6 you roll beyond the first to secondary targets within SHORT range of the primary target. The first assigned to a secondary target inflicts damage equal to the Damage rating of the weapon, any further assigned to a secondary target can be used for stunts.

u  If you roll any 1 on the RANGED COMBAT test – even if you did not Pray of the Icons – your ammo magazine is emptied.

 

⦿ Quick Shot

If there is no time for aiming, you can just shoot from the hip. This counts as a normal Shoot action, but with a few differences:

u  You get a -2 modification to your roll.

u  You can only fire a quick shot attack against enemies at Close Range or Short Range.

u  When you take this action more than once per round, when you roll any 1 on the RANGED COMBAT test – even if you did not Pray of the Icons – your ammo magazine is emptied.

 

⟣⟣⟣ Full Dodge

When attacked in ranged combat, you can try to focus on dodging. You can only dodge attacks from attackers that you’re aware of, and you must declare a Full Dodge before the attacker rolls. Full Dodge stays in effect until the end of the round for all ranged attacks on you.

Roll for DEXTERITY. Dodging turns the attack into an opposed roll – for each 6 you roll when dodging, you eliminate one 6 rolled by the attacker. NPCs consume 1 Darkness when they use this action.

 

⟣ Hit the Dirt!

If you’re attacked in ranged combat, you can drop yourself immediately to the floor. You must declare a Hit the Dirt before your roll for Armor (see p.16).

You gain a +2 armor rating bonus on your Armor roll, due to the sudden movement. You then go PRONE. NPCs consume 1 Darkness when they use this action.

 

⦿ Assume Overwatch

You can assume an overwatch position, if you hold a ranged weapon and no enemies are within ENGAGED range. You overwatch to a specified direction of max 45 degrees. Until the start of your next turn, you can fire your weapon against a target in the chosen direction. 

You can fire whenever you want in the turn order, and your shot is resolved before all other actions — even if they are already declared. For example, if an enemy in the direction you are aiming declares that they want to fire a weapon, you can shoot first. The enemy is not allowed to change their attack after your overwatch attack.

You can use the Shoot or Quick Shot actions as Reactive Actions while in overwatch position. 

Therefore, you must save actions in the Round for any overwatch attack you want to make.

If both you and an enemy assume overwatch positions against each other, and both choose to fire against each other, then an opposed RANGED COMBAT roll determines which attack goes first. This roll does not count as an action for either of you.

LOSING OVERWATCH: You keep your overwatch position as long as you do nothing but shoot in the chosen direction. If you perform any other action, the overwatch position is lost. It is also immediately lost if either of the following occurs:

u  You are attacked in close combat.

u  You suffer damage.

 

⟣ Covering Fire

You can only use this reaction after an ally is hit, but before they roll for Armor (see p.16). NPCs consume 1 Darkness when they use this action.

Roll for RANGED COMBAT. On a success, your ally gains a +1 armor rating bonus. This is cumulative of any armor and cover they already have. 

STUNTS: For every extra 6 you roll, choose one of these stunts:

u  Aggressive Fire: You strike fear into your enemy. They take 1 point of stress. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

u  Covering: Your ally receives a +1 armor rating bonus. This is cumulative of any armor and cover they already have. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

 

⦿ / ⟣ Suppresive Fire

Suppressive Fire can be used as a regular Action – or when you or an ally is attacked in ranged combat, as a Reactive Action. If used as a Reactive Action, you must declare it before the attacker rolls. NPCs consume 1 Darkness when they use this action.

Roll for RANGED COMBAT. On a success, your enemy takes 1 point of stress.

STUNTS: For every extra 6 you roll, choose one of these stunts:

u  Aggressive Fire: You strike fear into your enemy. They take 1 point of stress. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

u  Suppression: Your target receives a -1 modifier to their next RANGED COMBAT test. This effect can be chosen multiple times and is cumulative.

 

⦿⦿ Reload Weapon

You grab a magazine or an energy cell for your weapon and then reload your weapon so you can fire it again. NPCs consume 1 Darkness when they reload a weapon.

 

Interpersonal Activities

⦿ / ⦿⦿ / ⦿⦿⦿ Help Other

You help an ally perform an action, providing them with a +1 modification on their roll. This costs the same number of Actions as they use. You must declare that you are helping someone before any dice are rolled.

You need to act on the same Initiative as your ally, so you might need to Hold Off if you want to help.

 

⦿⦿ Administer First Aid

You can help an ally within close range to treat them. Roll a MEDICURGY test. Certain medical equipment can give modifications to the roll. 

If the roll is successful, choose one effect:

u  If broken by damage: they wake up immediately, regaining Health equal to the number of 6’s in the skill roll.

u  If suffering a lethal injury: the injury is stabilized and will not kill them when the time limit has passed.

u  If broken by fire damage: you prevent your patient from dying. See the Fire hazard rules on page 21.

 

⦿⦿ Recognize Weakness

You can recognize critical weaknesses in an enemy and communicate these to your allies. They must be able to hear you, even if via a comm radio. 

Choose a target and roll MEDICURGY. For every two 6’s you roll, you and your allies that manage to hit against the target with a close combat or ranged combat action before the end of your next turn, gain an extra success that they can spend on STUNTS.

 

⦿⦿ Give Orders

You can bark orders to an ally. They must be able to hear you, even if via a comm radio. Roll COMMAND. For every 6 you roll, they get a +1 modification to their roll when carrying out the order you gave.

 

⦿⦿ Stop Panic

When another character makes a Panic Roll and loses control, you can make a COMMAND roll to return them to their senses. They must be able to hear you, even if via a comm radio. See Stopping Panic on page 19.

On a success, your ally immediately loses any Panic effects and conditions that the Panic applied to them.

 

⦿⦿ Rally Ally

When another character is broken by stress, roll MANIPULATE or MEDICURGY to motivate and push them to press on. They must be able to hear you, even if via a comm radio. Each person can only try this once on a broken character.

On a success, they wake up to the situation immediately, regain Mind Points equal to the number of 6’s rolled and are no longer broken. Only broken victims can recover stress in this way.

 

⦿⦿⦿ MANIPULATE Someone

Lies, persuasion, threats, charm or seduction – there are many ways to make someone see things your way. If this action is used within a Combat encounter, you can only use a short statement. They must be able to hear you, even if via a comm radio. 

Roll an opposed MANIPULATE skill test. Apply any leverage modifiers (page 61 of the Core Rules). You always are affected by the risky situation factor during combat, so this test has a minimum of -1 modification.

On a success, your opponent must make a choice – either do as you want; or attack you physically. If they agree, they can demand something of you in return – the GM decides what. You can either accept the deal or back off.

STUNT: If you roll an extra 6, you can take this stunt:

u  Quick: Your persuasion only took two Actions.

u  Strike Fear: You strike fear into your enemy. They take 1 point of stress. This effect can be chosen multiple times.

u  Persuaded. Your opponent is so moved by the strength of your personality that she accepts your demands without asking for anything in return. This effect can only be chosen if your opponent agrees to do what you want. (cost: two 6’s)

 

Other Activities

⦿⦿⦿ Activate Mystical Power

You try to activate a mystical power. To activate it, you must pass a MYSTIC POWERS test. 

A failed roll means that the power does not activate properly – giving you incorrect information or resulting in some other undesired effect. The GM decides the details. 

Each use of a power always generates 1 Darkness. If you fail to activate a mystical power, you also take 1 stress.

 

⦿⦿ Break or Lift Something

You try to break or lift something. Roll a FORCE test, modified by the difficulty set by the GM. (page 59 of the Core Rules)

 

⦿⦿⦿ Interact with Technology

You interact with mechanical or electronic technology to reach a goal. Roll a DATA DJINN, PILOT, SURVIVAL or TECHNOLOGY test depending on the situation, as determined by the GM. 

Roll for the skill test, modified by the difficulty set by the GM. (page 59 of the Core Rules)

STUNT: If you roll an extra 6, you can take this stunt:

u  Quick: Your interaction only took two Actions.

 

⦿ Draw Weapon

You draw or swap a weapon you have ready on your person. (i.e. on a belt or on your back)

 

◯ Draw Tiny Item

You draw a tiny item (like an M-Dose) you have ready on your person. (i.e. on a belt or in your pocket)

 

⦿ Pick Up Item

You pick up an item within Close range from the floor.

 

⦿⦿ Retrieve Stowed Item

You retrieve an item or weapon that you had stowed away in a backpack, sack or similar container.

 

⦿ Stash item

You put away a weapon or item on your body. (i.e. on a belt or on your back)

 

⦿ Use Simple Item

You use a simple item like a stim, a dose or personal communicator.

 

⦿⦿⦿ Use Complex Item

You use a complex item like a gadget or artifact. This might require a skill test, as determined by the GM.

 

⦿⦿⦿ Coup de GrâCE

Can only be used against a broken character you have ENGAGED. A broken character is almost defenseless. If it’s a human being and you want to kill your target outright, roll for EMPATHY (attribute only). 

If you fail, roll on the Critical Injury table. Instead of D66, roll a D6 and add +60 to the result.

Whether or not you succeed at killing your target, you take 1 stress — killing in cold blood is not that easy. If you have the Executioner talent, you can roll a Critical Injury without an EMPATHY roll and stress.

 

⦿⦿⦿ Fire! Put it out! Put it Out!

You, or a friend within Close range, is on fire. You can stop the fire with a successful DEXTERITY test. See the Fire hazard rules on page 21.

 

⦿⦿⦿ Getting into an Exo Shell

If you want protection against the vacuum, you will need to get into an exo shell. You will need to succeed on a successful DEXTERITY test to do this.

 

◯ Quick Shout

You shout something up to 6 words. You can do this only once per turn.

 

◯ Release

You drop or release something you're holding in your hand or hands.

Damage

Life within the Third Horizon is risky and dangerous. You run the risk of being injured in combat. Everything from exhaustion to bleeding cuts and broken bones is summarized as damage. Damage taken reduces your Health points.

 

Armor & Cover

Armor and cover (see the Take Cover action) can protect you from damage. When you suffer damage from an attack, roll a number of dice equal to the armor rating of your armor and/or cover – if you have both armor and cover, add them together. 

For every six you roll, lower the damage by 1. If this lowers damage to 0, ignore all stunt effects. This is a passive roll.

 

Broken by Damage

If you drop to zero Health, you are broken by damage and collapse to the ground. You can mumble in pain and make one crawling move action per round – at 1/4th (rounded down) of your movement rate instead of half. You cannot perform any other actions.

Additional Damage: If you suffer additional damage while broken, you automatically suffer a critical injury.

Broken NPCs and Creatures: If a minor NPC or creature is broken by damage, the GM can simply decide that the NPC or creature is killed or taken out of action. For important NPCs or creatures, the GM can use the same rules as for player characters.

 

Recovering Health

Being broken by damage is not fatal in itself – only critical injuries can actually kill you. There are three ways to recover health, assuming you’re not dead.

u  First Aid: Someone can help you recover by giving you first aid (⦿⦿) and rolling for MEDICURGY. If successful, you heal damage equal to the number of 6’s rolled, and you are no longer broken. You are still PRONE until you get up. Only broken victims can recover Health in this way.

u  E-Dose: An E-Dose automatically heals 2 damage. You are no longer broken, if you were.

u  On Your Own: You automatically heal 1 point of damage every hour.

 

MEDICAL EQUIPMENT

The following two new items are Light items, Tech Tier (O) that costs 200 birr. A dose can be used on yourself or on someone else via the Use Simple Item action.

u  E-dose – A one-use injector with powerful stimulants and analgesics designed to restore combat function in an emergency situation. It heals 2 damage to your Health.

u  S-dose – Also called a stimpack, a psychoactive substance designed to suppress fear and hunger, increase wakefulness, and reduce empathy among active combatants. Highly addictive. It heals 2 stress to your Mind.

 

Stun Damage

Weapons with the Stun feature do not trigger critical injuries. Instead of the Critical Injury STUNT, they can use the following.

STUNTS: For every extra 6 you roll, choose one of these stunts:

u  Staggered: Your target loses one action in their next turn.

u  Stunned: Your target loses all actions in their next turn, and cannot use reactive actions until then. This effect costs 2 extra sixes (beyond the first one).

Dying From Lethal Injuries

Some critical injuries are listed as lethal. If you suffer such an injury, you will die after the listed time limit has passed, unless stabilized before then. To stabilize a lethal critical injury, someone must use the Administer First Aid action on you with a Medkit.

As long as you’re not broken, you can attempt to stabilize yourself. If the roll fails, the same person cannot try again unless they get access to better medical gear (with higher bonus).

 

Healing Critical Injuries

Each critical injury has specific effects that you suffer during the indicated healing time. If someone tends to you daily during the process of healing a critical injury, they roll MEDICURGY. On a success, the remaining healing time is reduced by half. Each critical injury requires its own MEDICURGY roll to shorten recovery

 

Conditions

In Coriolis Third Horizon, critical injuries, mental trauma injuries or other situations and effects can lead to conditions. Most conditions give you modification on all rolls related to attributes.

u  Confused: -2 WITS

u  Dazed: -2 AGILITY

u  Disheartened: -2 EMPATHY

u  Distracted: -1 AGILITY and -1 WITS

u  Exhausted: -2 STRENGTH

u  Shaken: -1 STRENGTH and -1 EMPATHY

u  Hampered: Your movement rate is halved.

u  Impeded: The Move activity costs two actions.

u  Shell-shocked: You lose your next 2 actions. If you don’t have enough actions left, you lose them in the next round and cannot use reactive actions until after your next turn.

u  Staggered: You have one action less each round.

u  Stunned: You lose your next 3 actions and cannot use reactive actions until after your next turn.

If you suffer from a condition that you already have, you must choose another condition. You automatically recover from a condition after 1 hour unless otherwise specified. (like with Shell-shocked or Stunned)

 

PROSTETICS

The following cybernetic implants and bionic sculpts can be used to replace a complete severed arm or leg, in addition to their other benefits. If you already have these when you get a severed arm or leg critical injury, you can fix them via a new medical procedure, costing half price.

u  Cybernetic Muscles (Core Rules p.75)

u  Endo Skeleton (Core Rules p.75)

u  Servo Locks (Core Rules p.75)

u  Morph (Core Rules p.76)

u  Nimble (Core Rules p.76)

Stress & Panic

Events within the Third Horizon are tumultuous and strained. You run the risk of being traumatized by combat, political scheming and the Dark. Everything from mental strain, collapsing from gear or experiencing anxiety is summarized as stress. Stress taken reduces your Mind points.

 

Gaining Stress

The mounting tension of your character is measured by taking stress. This decreases the stability and state of your mind during the course of the game. 

You gain 1 stress whenever one of the following happens:

u  Exert Yourself: When you gain an extra Action that can only be used for a Reactive Action. (no Panic Roll)

u  Disturbed Prayers: When you fail a pushed test and you rolled a 1 on any of the dice.

u  Strike Fear (STUNT): When you are stricken with fear by an enemy in melee combat or via manipulation.

u  Aggressive Fire (STUNT): When you are stricken with fear by an enemy in ranged combat.

u  Full Auto Fire: When you shoot with the Full Auto Fire action. (no Panic Roll)

u  Suppressive Fire: When you are hit by suppressive fire in ranged combat by an enemy.

u  Deprived: When you go without sleep, food, or water for a day.

u  Coup de Grâce: When you execute a helpless enemy by taking the Coup de Grâce action.

u  Friendly Fire. When you shoot a member of your own crew on accident.

u  Darkmorphs. When a darkmorph spawn appears.

u  Mystical Spirits. When a mystical spirit like a djinn appears.

u  Events. Certain events may cause you to gain stress, as determined by the GM or scenario.

 

Panic Roll

After you suffer stress, make a Panic Roll — unless the rules for that source of stress say otherwise.

Roll a D10 + your current Mind score. Compare the result to the table below. This is a passive roll. On a 7+, you keep your mind together and nothing happens.

Panic: On a failure, you receive a panic effect, and you can be forced to perform a specific panic action as the next thing you do.

More Panic: If you are already suffering from a panic event and fail another Panic Roll, replace the old effect with the new one. If the new effect is less severe, adjust the old one upward by one step instead (so your new panic effect is always worse than the previous effect).

PANIC ROLL

Result

Effect

1

Flee. You just can’t take it anymore. You must flee to a safe place and refuse to leave it.

You won’t attack anyone and won’t attempt anything dangerous. You can NOT use the Retreat action. You recover 1 stress. All allies who see you flee; and must make an immediate Panic Roll.

2

Scream. You scream your lungs out. You become Shell-shocked. All allies who hear you scream, must make an immediate Panic Roll.

3

Seek Cover. You must use your next actions to move away from danger and find a safe spot if possible. You are allowed to make a Retreat action. You can act normally once you’ve taken the Take Cover action.

4

Freeze. You’re frozen by fear or stress. You become Shell-shocked.

5

Drop Item. Whether by stress, confusion, or the realization that you’re all going to die anyway, you drop a weapon or other important item–the GM decides which one.

6

Tremble. You start to tremble uncontrollably. You become Distracted until the end of your next turn.

7+

Keeping it together. You manage to keep your nerves in check – this time.

 

NPCs: Most Humans, semi-intelligences and beasts can make Panic Rolls. Or they panic when the GM deems it appropriate. This is up to the GM's judgement.

 

Stopping Panic

Effects on the Panic Roll table remain in effect until one of the following happens:

u  Another character comes to your aid and makes a Stop Panic action (see page 14). On a success, all your Panic effects and conditions end immediately.

u  You are broken.

u  The effect runs out when it’s no longer applicable. (e.g. you stop fleeing if all danger has passed)


 

Broken by Stress

If you drop to zero Mind, you are broken by stress. You can make one move activity per round, but not perform any other actions as you are stressed out due to despair.

You also suffer a Mental Trauma – immediately roll on the mental trauma table. Any further stress while already broken has no effect.

 

Recovering your Mind

Being broken by stress won’t put you in the madhouse – only trauma will do that. There are three ways to recover your mind, assuming you’re not dead.

u  Rally Ally: Someone can help you recover by rallying you (⦿⦿) and rolling for MANIPULATE or MEDICURGY. If successful, you heal mind points equal to the number of 6’s rolled, and you are no longer broken. Only broken victims can recover stress in this way.

u  S-Dose: An S-Dose automatically heals 2 stress. You are no longer broken, if you were.

u  Resting Safely: You automatically heal 1 point of stress every 15 minutes spent in a non-stressful area that is secured from enemies (as far as you know). You cannot make any skill rolls when resting, and if your rest is interrupted, it doesn’t count. You cannot relieve stress in this way if you haven’t had any sleep, water or food in 24 hours.

 

Healing Trauma

If you have suffered a mental trauma, you may make an EMPATHY roll each week that you’re in a safe place (e.g. Coriolis Station or your ship) to recover from it. You must not do any stressful activities within that week. You cannot Pray to the Icons on this roll.

This does not apply to trauma that only gives you a condition (11~30) – these are healed after a full nights rest in a safe place.

MENTAL TRAUMA BUY IN

It is strongly recommended that you discuss mental injury in the group before using these rules. If anyone in the group prefers not to make mental illness a part of the game, be sure to respect that and simply ignore the rule that being broken by stress triggers mental trauma.

 

Mental Trauma

 

D66

Trauma

Effects

11-13

Trembling

You become Dazed.

14-16

Anxious

You become Shaken.

21-23

Sullen

You become Disheartened.

24-26

Delirium

You become Confused.

31-33

Changed personality

Choose a new personality. (see character creation)

34-36

Worrisome

Even minor concerns (GM’s choice) count as stressful situations for you. In such a situation, roll a successful EMPATHY or take 1 stress.

41-42

Nightmares

Make an OBSERVATION roll every night spent sleeping. Failure means that the sleep doesn’t count. (See Sleep Deprivation rules.)

43-44

Addict

You must consume a drug every day, or become Disheartened.

45-46

Apathetic

You cannot push any dice rolls by Praying to the Icons.

51-52

Phobic

You suffer 1 point of stress each round within Near range of the object of your phobia, which is connected to the traumatic event.

53-54

Claustrophobic

You suffer 1 point of stress every 15 minutes in a confined space.

55-56

Hallucinations

Every 6 hours, you experience an hallucination. Roll a successful EMPATHY or take 1 stress.

61

Mythomaniac

You cannot stop yourself from lying about everything.

62

Paranoia

You are certain that someone is out to get you.

63

Delusion

You are totally convinced of something that is totally untrue.

64

Amnesia

You lose all memory and cannot recollect who you or any of your friends are.

65

Catatonic

You stare into oblivion, and do not respond to any stimuli.

66

Heart attack

Your heart stops, and you die of pure fright.

 

Hazards

There are many hazards in the Third Horizon that you can cross on your path.

 

Fire

A fire is measured by its intensity. A typical fire has intensity 6–9. When entering a burning area, or starting a round in one, roll a number of dice equal to the intensity. For every 6 rolled, you suffer 1 point of damage. Armor has its normal effect.

Catching Fire: If you take damage from a fire attack, you catch fire and continue to burn. You suffer another attack at the start of each new round even if you leave the burning zone. As soon as a fire attack outside a burning area inflicts no damage, you’re no longer on fire. You, or a friend at ENGAGED range, can stop you from burning with a successful DEXTERITY roll (⦿⦿⦿).

Fire Crits: Fire doesn’t cause normal critical injuries. Instead, if you are broken by fire damage, or suffer

fire damage when already broken, you must make a FORCE roll on every turn until you are stabilized with a MEDICURGY roll. If a roll fails, you die.

 

Explosions

Some weapons like grenades have an explosive effect. You fire these as a normal ranged attack, but if you hit your target (which can be an empty space), all other characters within the effect radius suffer the same damage. Each target can dodge the attack separately. If your attack misses, the shot is assumed to have gone astray or been a dud and hurts no one.

Blast Power: The force of an explosion is measured in Blast Power. Roll a number of dice equal to the Blast Power. For every 6 rolled, the damage of the explosion gets increased by one. You cannot Pray to the Icons on this roll.

Blast Radius: Each person within the NEAR blast radius suffers the damage.

Powerful explosives, with a Blast Power of 7 or more, can harm people even at SHORT range. Half the damage for the targets outside the NEAR radius but within the SHORT radius.

Placed Charges: Breach charges (Core Rules p.129) don’t roll to hit and automatically do damage to everything within their blast radius. Targets at ENGAGED range from the explosive suffer double damage.

 

Vacuum

Space is a cold and unforgiving place. Without the protection of a space suit or the hull of a ship, you won’t last long in the black void. If your ship suffers explosive decompression (below) or if you are thrown out of an air lock, your life is in extreme danger. The absence of pressure creates gas bubbles in your blood, causing your whole body to swell up. This results in crippling pain, all while the raw UV radiation from the nearest star sears your skin. You can’t hold your breath—if you do, your lungs collapse. After that, you are just moments away from death. 

You must make a FORCE roll on each turn before you can take an action, until you die or enter a pressurized area. The roll itself is not an action. The first roll is unmodified, but you get -1 dice on the second roll, -2 on the third roll, and so on. A failed roll means you drop directly to zero Health and become broken.

Continue to make FORCE rolls on every turn, now unmodified. If you fail this roll before being brought to safety, you die.

Before being broken, you should put all your efforts towards getting a space suit on, if one can be found nearby. Climbing into a space suit quickly (⦿⦿⦿) requires a successful DEXTERITY roll.

Explosive Decompression: If the bulkhead of a spaceship fails, the air will vent out into space within one round. The intense draft will require everyone to make a FORCE roll on their turn to perform any action. The roll itself is not an action. Most ships will automatically seal off a breached compartment. Once the air is gone, anyone still in the vented compartment will suffer the effects of vacuum.

 

Falling

Falling on a hard surface automatically inflicts an amount of damage to you equal to the height of the fall (in meters) divided by 2, rounding down. Each point of damage after the first two, triggers one critical injury each.

In a controlled jump, roll DEXTERITY. Each 6 rolled reduces the damage done by 1.

 

Zero Gravity

Most ships and stations have artificial gravity generators, but these can fail. You can also find yourself spacewalking outside your ship. In an area without gravity, all rolls for FORCE and DEXTERITY get -2 dice.

In addition, unless you have the Zero-G Training talent, every move activity requires a successful DEXTERITY roll (without the penalty), with failure meaning you spin in place and suffer 1 stress. 

On the flip side, zero gravity allows you to move in any direction, floating through open air (or space). And you never risk falling damage.

 

Radiation

You can get exposed to radiation in many situations – on a spacewalk near a star, or when you try to repair your shuttle’s leaking reactor core. When you are exposed to radiation, you take damage as the radiation accumulates in your body.

When you are exposed to radiation, you gain Radiation Points, or Rads, that accumulate in your body. The area’s Radiation Level determines how

often you get Rads:

u  WEAK RADIATION: 1 Rad per hour

u  STRONG RADIATION: 1 Rad per 15 minutes

u  EXTREME RADIATION: 1 Rad per round

Effects: Every time you gain a Radiation Point, you must roll a number of dice equal to your total current number of accumulated Rads. For every 6, you take one point of damage.

If broken by damage in an irradiated area, you must make a FORCE roll each time you get another Rad, until you are brought to safety. If such roll fails, you die from radiation poisoning. As long as you remain broken inside an irradiated area, you cannot recover Health in any way.

Recovery: After you leave the irradiated area, you heal one Rad per hour.

Permanent Radiation: There is a risk that the radiation will permanently stay in your body. Every time you are about to heal a Rad, roll a die. If it shows 6, the Rad is not healed but instead becomes permanent. Permanent radiation can never be healed.

 

Drowning

All player characters are assumed to know how to swim. For the purposes of movement, swimming counts as crawling.

If you end up in water, you need to make a DEXTERITY roll every 15 minutes to stay afloat. 

Under water, you need to make a FORCE roll every round to hold your breath. If you fail, you start to drown and suffer one point of damage every round until someone saves you. If you are broken by damage while drowning, you die after 15 minutes.

 

Cold & Heat

If exposed to cold or heat and you don’t have adequate clothes, equipment or shelter (GMs discretion), you must roll for FORCE at regular intervals. 

The more extreme the temperature is, the more frequently you need to roll. For instance, on a frozen moon or dry desert planet you have to roll once every 6 hours, or even every 15 minutes if the conditions are particularly bad.

If you fail, you become hypothermic or overheated, suffer one point of damage and become Exhausted and Confused. You also cannot recover your Health or Mind.

You must keep rolling FORCE at the same interval, suffering another point of damage each time you fail. If you are broken while hypothermic or overheated, keep rolling FORCE at the same intervals. If you fail a roll before being brought to safety, you die from the exposure.

 

Hunger & Thirst

It’s rare to get in such a survival situation, but it’s no fun.

Hunger: If you lack sufficient food, you suffer 1 point of damage and stress every 48 hours and become Exhausted.

Thirst: You become dehydrated if you haven’t drunk any water. You suffer 1 point of damage and stress every 12 hours and become Dazed.

 

Sleep Deprivation

You need to sleep for at least 6 hours each day. After one day without sleep, you gain 1 stress every 6 hours and become Confused. You also cannot recover your Mind.

If you are broken by stress while sleep deprived, you collapse and sleep for at least 6 hours, and are unable to wake up during that time.

As soon as you have slept for at least 6 hours, you are no longer sleep deprived or Confused.

 

Suffocation

Your chest burns and the world narrows as every breath you are denied, drags you closer to the dark.

You need to make a FORCE roll every round to hold your breath. If you fail, you start to suffocate and suffer one point of damage every round until someone saves you. If you are broken by damage while suffocating, you die after 15 minutes.

 

Poison

A poison is measured by its toxicity. A weak poison has toxicity 3, a strong poison has toxicity 5, and an extremely potent poison can have toxicity 8 or even more. If you ingest poison, make an opposed roll for FORCE against the toxicity. 

If you fail the roll, you suffer its effect below. Antidotes can halt the effect of a poison.

u  Lethal Poison: You take one point of damage on your turn each round until you are broken. The turn after that you roll again to resist the poison. If you fail, you die.

u  Paralyzing Poison: You cannot move or perform any actions for 15 minutes.

u  Sleeping Poison: You fall asleep, unable to wake up for 6 hours. Waking pills work as an antidote to this type of poison.

Disease

When exposed to a dangerous contagion or infection, make an opposed roll for FORCE against the virulence rating of the disease. A typical disease has a virulence of 5, but there are diseases with much higher virulence.

If you fail the roll, you fall ail, which means you suffer one point of damage and cannot recover damage. Make another roll against the disease once per day. Each failed roll means you suffer another point of damage.

If you are broken by damage while sick, you die after another day if you’re not given aid before then. As soon as you win a roll against the disease, you are no longer ill. Stop rolling infection rolls and heal your damage normally.

Recovery from Disease: If you are cared for by someone during your sickness, this person can roll against your disease instead of you. The caregiver rolls for MEDICURGY and adds any bonuses from appropriate talents and medical gear.

This compendium replaces the Combat chapter of the Coriolis Third Horizon Core Rulebook. The following changes are made to the Core rules to rebalance them in reflection to the rules in this compendium.

 

Cover

As seen in the Take Cover action on page 10, the armor rating of all covers are doubled. This promotes tactical play where you shoot from cover.

Core Rulebook p.93

 

Damage

The DAMAGE ratings of all Ordinary and Advanced technology weapons are increased by 1.

This is to increase the lethality of weapons, so it promotes tactical play to get into cover.

Core Rulebook p.126-127, 130

 

Explosives and Grenades

The DAMAGE ratings of all explosives and grenades are increased by 2.

The RADIUS of all explosives and grenades with Close range, have a changed radius to the new Near range that is introduced on page 8. (4 meters instead of 2)

Concussion and frag grenades have their DAMAGE ratings switched around.

Core Rulebook p.129.

This chapter adds new talents. Some talents might have a prerequisite of another talent or an increased cost.

 

☀︎ COMBAT MEDIC

You have been trained to heal during the heat of battle, even while your patient is moving around in combat. You may perform the Administer First Aid action even when they aren't broken by damage. An ally can only be healed in this way once per hour.

 

☀︎ Calming Presence

Your voice is a calming presence on your allies. You can perform the Rally Ally action on allies that aren't broken by stress. An ally can only recover stress in this way once per hour.

 

☀︎ Synthurge

You have specialized in synthesizing drugs. When you succeed on the Administer First Aid action, you can also select the following options. The target never rolls a Panic test due to Synthurge.

u  Ashbone: Your target gains a +1 bonus to the damage of their melee attacks until the end of their next turn, after which they suffer 1 stress.

u  Breath of Dura: Your target recovers 1 stress but also suffers 1 damage.

u  Kambra: Your target suffers 1 stress, but takes the result of 10 on their next Panic roll within 1 minute.

u  Zulami: Your target gains two extra Action Points that they can only use for Reactive Actions in the current and in the next turn, after which they suffer 1 stress.

 

☀︎ Rioting Djinn

You slice into a target’s communicator (I-II), holograph (I-II), or primitive computer, creating a disadvantage by interfering with a critical system—such as distorting their vision feed, disrupting their armor controls, or triggering a distracting alert. This requires you to use an ordinary or advanced computer. When you perform the Interact with Technology action with those conditions, you can alternatively select the following stunts:

u  Incoming Call: Your target becomes Distracted until the end of their next turn.

u  Popups: Your target becomes Confused until the end of their next turn.

u  Riot: Your target becomes Dazed until the end of their next turn.

 

☀︎ Inspiring Aura

You must be holding a talisman or other inspiring item in one hand. When you perform the Give Order action with those conditions, you can alternatively select the following stunts:

u  Inspiring Aura: All allies within Near range who can see you, gain a +1 modifier on one simple skill of your choosing until the start of your next turn. An ally can only use this bonus on one roll.

u  Empowering Presence: You increase the range of your Inspiring Aura stunt to Short range until the start of your next turn.

 

☀︎ Back to Back

Requires: Inspiring Aura | Cost: 10 XP
You must be holding a talisman or other inspiring item in one hand. When you perform the Give Order action with those conditions, you can alternatively select the following stunts:

u  Cadence Call: All allies within Near range who can see you each gain +1 Action Point. This bonus Action Point can only be used for Reactive Actions before the start of their next turn, and only if they are standing beside another ally.

u  Empowering Presence: You increase the range of your Inspiring Aura stunt to Short range until the start of your next turn.

 

☀︎ Wired Reflexes

CYBERWARE | Cost: 10,000 birr, 10 XP
Painful neural implants sharpen your reflexes, letting you dodge bullets. By taking 1 stress (no Panic roll), you can perform the Full Dodge action without spending Action Points.

More Talents?

The community has created multiple great expansions on www.drivethrurpg.com:

u  Coriolis: Veterans of the Horizon

u  Coriolis: Quiet Victories

u  Coriolis: Expanded Horizons

u  Coriolis: Web of the Dataspider

u  Coriolis: Combat Elite

Rolling Dice

To attempt something difficult or dangerous, roll a number of six-sided dice equal to your skill plus related attribute score that best matches the challenge at hand. To succeed, you need to roll at least one 6.

When to Roll: Generally, this rulebook or the adventure will indicate when to roll dice and what attribute or skill to roll for. However, the GM can always call for a roll in a situation they feel warrants it. This is sometimes called a test. Avoid rolling for trivial situations — reserve dice rolls for dramatic or uncertain moments where real stakes are involved.

Stunts

If you roll more than one 6 in a skill roll, you can achieve bonus effects called stunts. For attacks, the stunts are specified in the Combat Actions chapter.

In other situations, a stunt could mean any number of things, specified by the adventure or suggested by the GM or yourself. Some examples:

u  You show off.

u  You do it quickly.

u  You do it quietly.

u  You achieve some unexpected additional effect.

The GM has final say on what stunts can be used in any situation.

Roll Modifiers

The rules, the adventure scene, or the GM can modify your chances of success, adding or removing dice for you to roll. 

Bonuses and penalties are expressed as dice modifiers (e.g., +1 die, –2 dice). You always roll at least one die.

Gear: Equipment may provide bonus dice, but sometimes simply owning the right item is required before you can attempt the action at all.

Failure

If no 6 is rolled, you fail. Describe together with the GM how the attempt went wrong — and whether it creates new complications or dangers. They might even let a roll have further consequences to move the story forward in a dramatic way. You have one last chance if you really need to succeed – you can push the roll.

Pushing Your Roll

If you fail a roll (or want more 6’s for stunts), you may push the roll by Praying to the Icons. Gather all dice that did not show a 6 and roll them again. All results count, including dice that were not re-rolled.

If you fail a test after pushing, and if at least one die shows a 1, you take 1 point of stress. Praying to the Icons also always generates 1 point of Darkness.

Passive Rolls: You can only push active rolls (when you choose to act). Passive rolls (like armor rolls or spotting an ambush) cannot be pushed and don’t cost an action.

Only Once: You can normally only push a roll once. Certain talents can allow you to push a roll twice, however.

NPCs: The GM makes dice rolls for NPCs in the same way as players for their characters. Important NPCs may push rolls, but each push consumes 1 Darkness. Use this sparingly to keep the tension focused on the players.

Help From Others

Up to three allies can assist on a roll. If it’s an Advanced skill, helpers must have at least 1 skill rank in that skill. 

Each helper adds +1 die, but only if they can clearly contribute to the action. For example: two crew members hold down a door while a third helps you weld it shut, giving +3 dice total.

Opposed Rolls

Sometimes rolling a 6 isn’t enough to succeed with your attribute or skill test. In opposed rolls, both sides roll as normal. Each 6 cancels out one of the opponent’s 6’s. Whoever has at least one 6 remaining wins.

Only the initiator can Pray to the Icons.

Breaking a Tie: If you and your opponent roll the same number of 6’s, the result is a tie. Typically, your action will fail if you roll a tie as the active party in an opposed roll, but in some cases, ties have specific effects. If a tie needs to be broken, re-roll the opposed roll to determine the outcome.

Health, the Mind and the Dark

Life in the Third Horizon is harsh and fleeting. To measure how much trauma you can take, the game uses three numeric ratings: Health, Mind and Darkness.

 

Health

Health represents your vitality and stamina. Health is degraded and broken by damage. Your maximum Health equals the sum of your STRENGTH and AGILITY scores.

 

Mind

The mind represents your resolve and willpower. Mind is degraded and broken by stress. Your maximum Mind equals the sum of your WITS and EMPATHY scores.

 

Darkness

The Icons are the hope of mankind, and the Dark between the Stars has always been its doom. Darkness is a shared pool managed by the GM that represents everything that can go wrong in the universe – the dark that pushes against reality.

Character Improvement

Your character will not stride unaffected through the Third Horizon. Your adventures will change you – this is the only certainty in an uncertain world.

Experience Points

Everyone gets 1 XP after each session for progressing the story. When progressing past a major milestone, determined by the GM, you might earn another XP. At the end of the session, ask the players the following questions. If at least one of these questions answer “yes”, everyone gains 1 extra XP:

u  Did we spend significant time roleplaying about a player characters personal problem?

u  Did we spend significant time learning new depths about a player character?

u  Did we spend significant time acting in accordance with our Icons?

SHORTER CAMPAIGN?

The experience gains above are suggested for longer campaigns. If you’re doing a shorter adventure or module only, it is suggested to gain 1 extra XP for each question answered yes.

 

Improving your character

When improving your character using experience, you need to spend a logical in-game downtime interval, and explanation that makes sense. In some cases, you need to ﬁnd a teacher, spend the effort, or go on a mission, before you can take a talent. An example of this is the Licensed talent.

u  Increase Attribute costs 6x its new level in XP; You cannot increase your total attribute points higher than 15. Only your Key Attribute can be raised to 5.

u  Getting a new skill to level 1, costs 5 XP. Raising a skill costs 3x new level in XP.

u  A talent costs 5 XP.

 

Emergent Mystical Power

If you gain your first Mystical Power without already being a fugitive mystic, your Reputation decreases by 1.

 

The Darkness Between the Stars

Darkness is generated when:

u  A player pushes a roll via a prayer to the Icons

u  A player activates a mystical power

u  The crew performs a Portal Jump

u  The crew travels through deep Space

u  Events related to the Dark between the Stars manifest

u  A character suffers a terrifying or shameful experience

Darkness is consumed via random events, but also GM chosen events.

 

The Chaotic Dark

At the start of each scene, and at the end of each combat round, the GM rolls dice equal to the current Darkness Points. On two or more 6’s, roll once on the Chaos Darkness table. 

If there are not enough Darkness Points left to pay the cost, reroll until a valid result appears.”

The Eventful Dark

The GM can also choose to consume Darkness in certain situations.

u  Push. Just like the PCs can pray to the Icons to get a reroll, the GM can reroll a skill test for an NPC. Consumes 1 Darkness.

u  Take the Initiative. An NPC moves to the top of the initiative order. Consumes 1 Darkness.

u  Reaction. An NPC can use a Reactive Action. Consumes 1 Darkness.

u  Reloading. An NPC can use a Reload Action. Consumes 1 Darkness.

u  Friendly Fire. Only usable if a PC shot at an NPC that has a different PC ENGAGED and missed. This inflicts damage equal to the weapon’s Damage rating to the PC that is ENGAGED. Consumes 1 Darkness.

u  Ammo Emptied. Only usable if a PC pushed a Shoot action and they rolled any 1 on the dice after the reroll. The PC’s weapon is out of ammo and needs to be reloaded. Consumes 1 Darkness.

u  Reinforcements. The enemy receives unexpected backup. Decide the details as the GM. Consumes 1-3 Darkness, depending on the reinforcements.

u  NPC Abilities. Many NPCs have abilities that consume Darkness when activated.

u  Story Events. Adventures often have events that consume Darkness when activated.

Example event: “Explosive Decompression” The PCs suddenly hear the hull creaking and sighing nearby. A successful OBSERVATION or SCIENCE test can tell them what is about to happen – the wall is about to give way and expose them to the vacuum of space! The automated security systems quickly lock all bulkhead doors around them. Those who passed the OBSERVATION or SCIENCE test get a +2 to their subsequent FORCE or DEXTERITY rolls. The section of the ship contains an exo locker. Consumes 1 Darkness.
